content: The "SCHIP Expansion Act of 2004" allows all uninsured children to be eligible for SCHIP. The "SCHIP Expansion Act of 2004" allows all uninsured children to be eligible for SCHIP. Amendments to Section 2110(b) of the Social Security Act include removing certain subparagraphs and paragraphs. Amendments to Section 2110(b)(3) of the Social Security Act prohibit excluding children with access to high-cost coverage from being treated as targeted vulnerable children. Amendments to the Social Security Act prevent children with access to expensive coverage from being classified as targeted vulnerable children. Amendments to the Social Security Act change "targeted low-income" to "targeted vulnerable" and address children with family income exceeding 200 percent of the poverty line. Effective date is October 1, 2004. SEC. 3. Increase in federal financial participation under SCHIP and Medicaid for states with simplified enrollment and renewal procedures for children. The amendment to Section 2105(c)(2) of the Social Security Act increases federal financial participation for states with simplified enrollment and renewal procedures under SCHIP and Medicaid for children. The limitation on expenditures for certain items does not apply to these states. The amendment increases federal financial participation for states with simplified enrollment and renewal procedures under SCHIP and Medicaid for children, exempting them from certain expenditure limitations. Additionally, the enhanced FMAP for a State may be increased by 5 percentage points for carrying out specific outreach strategies for children under title XIX. The amendment allows for a 5 percentage point increase in federal financial participation for states with simplified enrollment and renewal procedures under SCHIP and Medicaid for children. This increase is exempt from certain expenditure limitations and can be further enhanced by carrying out specific outreach strategies for children under title XIX. The State adopts 12-month continuous eligibility for children under title XIX and title XIX, eliminating asset tests for eligibility. The State implements passive renewal of children's eligibility for assistance under title XIX and title XIX if no changes are reported in family income or circumstances. The State implements passive renewal of children's eligibility for assistance under title XIX and title XIX if no changes are reported in family income or circumstances. Medicaid Section 1902(l) of the Social Security Act is amended to allow for expenditures incurred for outreach activities. The Federal medical assistance percentage for outreach strategies for individuals under 19 years of age eligible for medical assistance is equal to the enhanced FMAP, but only if the State carries out the same strategies for children under title XXI, including presumptive eligibility. The State must adopt 12-month continuous eligibility and eliminate asset tests for individuals eligible for assistance under title XXI. Automatic renewal of eligibility is also required for such individuals. The amendments made by this section allow for assistance under title XXI without reporting changes to family income, effective October 1, 2004. Elimination of SCHIP DIP and increase in funding. The Social Security Act is amended to increase funding for certain paragraphs, with amounts being adjusted upwards. The effective date for these changes is October 1, 2004, and they apply to allotments and redistributions made on or after that date. SEC. 5. LIMITATION ON PAYMENTS TO STATES WITH ENROLLMENT CAPS BUT UNUSED ALLOTMENTS. Section 2105 of the Social Security Act is amended to include a limitation on payments to states with enrollment caps that have not used their available allotments. Payment will not be made to a state if they have enrollment restrictions in place and have not exhausted their funding. The State will not receive payment if they have enrollment restrictions and have not fully expended available funding for child health assistance applications. States can still establish regular open enrollment periods. The amendments made by this section regarding health assistance take effect on October 1, 2004. Section 2107(e)(1) of the Social Security Act is amended to include requirements for managed care under SCHIP, effective October 1, 2004.
